Phrase 1: Donde está el baño Meaning: "Where's the restroom?" Phrase 2: No hablo castellano Meaning: "I don't speak Spanish" Phrase 3: Hablás inglés Meaning: Do you speak English ? Phrase 4: Salud Meaning: Cheers - bless you (when someone sneezes) Phrase 5: Cuanto sale Meaning: How much does it cost? Phrase 6: Donde está Sabi Meaning: Where is Sabi?
Phrase 1: "No worries, mate, she'll be right" Meaning: "Reflects a national stoicism that suggests everything (she) will turn out fine in the end. This being the case, there's no real point in worrying about anything." Phrase 2: Hit the frog and toad Meaning: "Different to having a frog in your throat, which means having a sore throat. Hitting the frog and toad is when you hit the road. Get out of 'ere." Phrase 3: One for the road Meaning: "A last drink before going home. Said at bars or friend's houses before going home." Phrase 4: Cooee Meaning: "A loud, Aboriginal cry in the outback that tells people where you are, assuming they're within cooee range." Phrase 5: Have a go, you mug Meaning: Generally refers to anyone who isn\'t putting in a full effort or taking any risks. Phrase 6: Smoko, garbo, bowlo, bottlo, arvo Meaning: "An "o" is the suffix to any word it can shorten. If in doubt, throw an "o" on the end of the word and it's bound to be Australian. e.g. A break when you smoke is a "smoko." Someone who collects garbage is a "garbo." " Phrase 7: "Bushman's handkerchief" Meaning: Not really a handkerchief at all, but using your hands to delicately drain the snot from your nose.
Phrase 1: Bom dia (boa tarde) Meaning: Good morning (good afternoon) Phrase 2: Como vai você? Meaning: How are you? Phrase 3: Você fala inglês? Meaning: Do you speak English? Phrase 4: Tudo bem? Meaning: A super-common informal greeting. “How’s it going?” (lit. “Everything good?”) Phrase 5: O Brasil é lindo maravilhoso! Meaning: Brazil is magnificent! Phrase 6: Valeu Meaning: Valeu is an informal way to say ‘thanks’ and would translate to ‘cheers’ in English. Phrase 7: Tranquilo Meaning: ranquilo literally translates into ‘tranquil’, but it usually is used to mean ‘it’s ok’ or ‘yeah, sure’.
Phrase 1: Keener Meaning: A person who is extremely eager, zealous, or enthusiastic. Phrase 2: Klick Meaning: This term refers to kilometers, the unit of length in the metric system equal to 1,000m. Phrase 3: Two-four Meaning: This term is commonly used to refer to a case of 24 beers. Phrase 4: Eh? Meaning: Pronounced “ay.” This word is used in everyday Canadian vernacular to indicate that you don’t understand something, It’s similar to the phrases “huh,” “right?” and “what?”. Phrase 5: What you sayin’? Meaning: One of those Canadian sayings that can be misleading. It’s used when asking what someone is doing – similar to the phrase “What are you up to?” Phrase 6: Molson Muscle Meaning: Here’s another great Canadian phrase for you, the Molson Muscle. It’s what Canadians call a beer belly.
Phrase 1: " 水满则溢。(Shuǐmǎn zé yì. 'water full but overflows') — Water flows in only to flow out. " Meaning: Similar to "what comes up must come down", this proverb points out that: things reverse when they reach their extremes. It\'s from the 18th century novel "A Dream of Red Mansions". Phrase 2: 三个和尚没水喝。 (Sān gè héshàng méi shuǐ hē. - three monks have no water to drink — Too many cooks spoil the broth. Meaning: I.e. if too many people try to do something, like three monks trying to carry one bucket of water, they make a mess of it. Phrase 3: Nǐ hǎo ma? (Nee-haoww-mah?) 你好吗 Meaning: How are you? Phrase 4: Xièxie. (sshyeah-sshyeah) 谢 谢 Meaning: This is the basic and simple way to say thank you. Phrase 5: Duōshao qián? 多少钱 (Dwor-sshaoww chyen?) Meaning: The phrase duōshao? is composed of the words duō (much) and shǎo (few), and means how much? or how many? Qián means money. Phrase 6: Wǒ xiǎng qù… (Wor sshyang chyoo …) 我想去 … Meaning: The three words are: wǒ (I), xiǎng (want), and qù (to go). Then add the name of the place. This is useful for buying train tickets, taking a taxi, etc.
Phrase 1: Bienvenue. Meaning: Welcome Phrase 2: Madame/Monsieur/Mademoiselle Meaning: Mrs. /Mr. /Miss Phrase 3: Parlez-vous anglais? Meaning: Do you speak English? Phrase 4: Merci beaucoup Meaning: Thank you very much Phrase 5: Être dans la galère. - To be in the galley Meaning: To get yourself into a mess Phrase 6: Pisser dans un violon - To piss in a violin Meaning: To waste your efforts
Phrase 1: Das ist mir Wurst - This is sausage to me Meaning: This expressions is used if you are indifferent or don’t care about something. Phrase 2: Jemandem die Daumen drücken - To press your thumbs for someone Meaning: In Germany they use this expression to wish someone good luck. It is often also accompanied with someone raising their fists and showing you that they are literally pressing their thumbs for you. Phrase 3: Ich glaub mein Schwein pfeift - I think my pig whistles Meaning: Germans use the phrase when they cannot believe something to be true or to express that they’re really surprised. Phrase 4: Fix und fertig sein - To be fixed and finished Meaning: his phrase is commonly used to express that you are completely exhausted. Phrase 5: Jemandem auf den Keks gehen - To go on someone’s cookie Meaning: It is used to express that someone is getting on our nerves. Phrase 6: Die Nase voll haben - To have the nose full Meaning: This expression is just another, more creative, way of saying “enough is enough”. It’s often used when someone is fed up with a particular situation and no longer wants to talk about it.
Phrase 1: Jugaad Meaning: The Oxford English Dictionary defines the word jugaad as “a flexible approach to problem-solving that uses limited resources in an innovative way”. Phrase 2: Ghanta Meaning: While the literal translation of ghanta is “bell”, it has become a common slang term in India. It expresses disbelief and is close in comparison to the phrase “yeah, right!” Phrase 3: Dhinchak Meaning: It’s similar in meaning to “bling”, but dhinchak applies to a lot of other things and isn’t limited to jewellery. A dhinchak person, for instance, is someone who tries to show a lot of swag. Phrase 4: Waat Lag Gayi Meaning: It means “ I am screwed!” or “We are screwed!” or “We are in the middle of a big screw-up” Phrase 5: Pandu Meaning: This word is used to refer to a police constable or a traffic police official. Sometimes it is also replaced by the commonly used “Mama” which means “Uncle” but in this case – a policeman. Phrase 6: Shaane Meaning: It simply means “You smart-ass!” or when used sarcastically, it could mean – “Do you think you are a smart ass?”
Phrase 1: Al mal tiempo, buena cara. Meaning: Put a good face to the bad times. Be positive. Phrase 2: Barriga llena, corazón contento. Meaning: Full stomach, happy heart. Phrase 3: Güey (also spelled “wey”) Meaning: Güey translates roughly to “dude” or “man” in Mexico. Phrase 4: Al mal tiempo, buena cara. Meaning: To bad times a good face. Put a good face to the bad times. Be positive. Phrase 5: Camarón que se duerme se lo lleva la corriente. Meaning: The shrimp that falls asleep is swept away by the current. You snooze, you lose. Phrase 6: A fuerza, ni los zapatos entran. Meaning: You can’t force your shoes to fit. You can’t force your way into anything.
Phrase 1: Just popping to the dairy. Meaning: I’m going to the convenience store. Phrase 2: Wop-wops - Middle of nowhere Meaning: The wop-wops are often teamed with the phrase tiki-tour, which refers to “taking the long way round,” or just getting totally and utterly lost. Phrase 3: Get your A into G! - Rattle ya dags! Meaning: Another way to say “hurry up,” the full sentence is actually: “Get your arse into gear!” Phrase 4: It was choice, bro! - It was good. Meaning: “Choice” is a versatile word in New Zealand, and pretty much means anything that’s positive — “ok,” “cool,” “I agree,” “I understand,” “It’s been good.” Phrase 5: Yeah-nah - No, thank you. Meaning: Even though it reads like both a yes and a no, yeah-nah is basically just a polite no. Phrase 6: BUGGER Meaning: You can use bugger when something goes wrong. It’s mostly heard on a farm. This NZ slang is basically a curse word. Phrase 7: "He looks a bit SUS” OR “That's a bit SUS " Meaning: When a situation or someone is particularly suspicious. Phrase 8: Piece of piss Meaning: This basically means when something is easy.
Phrase 1: How bodi? - How you dey? Meaning: How are you doing today? Phrase 2: I no sabi Meaning: I don’t understand Phrase 3: Amebo Meaning: This slang word is used to refer to a person who likes to gossip or likes to spread gossip. Phrase 4: Control(Ctrl) P Meaning: A recent slang in the Nigerian slang lexicon, ‘control P’ is a term used when someone is taking a situation too personally. Phrase 5: Fall my hand Meaning: This is another popular slang that is used when someone is disappointed by a person or something that happened. Phrase 6: Who dey Breeett? Meaning: It means “who is breathing?” in Pidgin English.
Phrase 1: Slap chips Meaning: Slap chips [slup chips] is a slang phrase for deep-fried potato chips sold at takeaway seafood shops, grocery stores and restaurants. Phrase 2: Braai Meaning: Braai [br-eye] is a widely used noun and verb for an outdoor ‘barbecue’ where meat is cooked over a fire or coals. Phrase 3: Boerewors Meaning: Boerewors [boor-uh-vors] is an Afrikaans term for ‘farmer’s sausage’ — a traditional South African meat often enjoyed at a braai. Phrase 4: Jol Meaning: Jol [jawl] is a widely-used term for ‘club’, ‘party’ or to ‘have fun’. Eg. ‘We had a jol last night!’ Phrase 5: Dankie - dunkey Meaning: Thank you Phrase 6: Howzit? Meaning: How are you?
